column1: 6 “To Kill a Mockingbird” is a significant novel by Harper Lee that explores themes of racial injustice and moral
growth. In the story, the jury plays a crucial role in the trial of Tom Robinson, a Black man falsely accused of raping
a white woman, Mayella Ewell. Despite clear evidence of his innocence and a compelling defense by Atticus Finch,
the all-white jury convicts Tom Robinson, reflecting the deep-seated racial prejudices of the time123.

column2: he jury’s decision is a pivotal moment in the book, highlighting the societal issues of the American South during
